pageProps.contentHtml:
residue theorem, Riemann Zeta function

Consider the function defined for s∈(1,∞)s \in \p{1, \infty}s∈(1,∞) by

f(s)=∫0∞xs−1ex−1 dx.f\p{s} = \int_0^\infty \frac{x^{s-1}}{e^x - 1} \,\diff{x}.f(s)=∫0∞​ex−1xs−1​dx.

Show that fff has an analytic continuation to {s∈C∣Re⁡s>0,s≠1}\set{s \in \C \mid \Re{s} > 0, s \neq 1}{s∈C∣Res>0,s=1} with a simple pole at s=1s = 1s=1. Compute the residue at s=1s = 1s=1.
Solution.

We have as−1=e(s−1)log⁡aa^{s-1} = e^{\p{s-1}\log{a}}as−1=e(s−1)loga for a>0a > 0a>0. We split fff up into

f(s)=∫01xs−1ex−1 dx+∫1∞xs−1ex−1 dx≕I1(s)+I2(s).f\p{s} = \int_0^1 \frac{x^{s-1}}{e^x - 1} \,\diff{x} + \int_1^\infty \frac{x^{s-1}}{e^x - 1} \,\diff{x} \eqqcolon I_1\p{s} + I_2\p{s}.f(s)=∫01​ex−1xs−1​dx+∫1∞​ex−1xs−1​dx=:I1​(s)+I2​(s).

Notice that

I2(s)=(∫1∞∑n=0∞(log⁡x)nex−1 dx)(s−1)n=∑n=0∞(∫1∞(log⁡x)nex−1 dx)(s−1)n,I_2\p{s} = \p{\int_1^\infty \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{\p{\log{x}}^n}{e^x - 1} \,\diff{x}}\p{s - 1}^n = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \p{\int_1^\infty \frac{\p{\log{x}}^n}{e^x - 1} \,\diff{x}}\p{s - 1}^n,I2​(s)=(∫1∞​n=0∑∞​ex−1(logx)n​dx)(s−1)n=n=0∑∞​(∫1∞​ex−1(logx)n​dx)(s−1)n,

by the monotone convergence theorem, since each term in the sum is non-negative. Since I2I_2I2​ has no singularities, this series expansion is valid on the entire complex plane, so I2I_2I2​ is entire.

It remains to show that I1I_1I1​ is analytic on the right-half plane except at s=1s = 1s=1. Observe that

g(s)≔I1(s)−1s−1=∫01xs−1(1ex−1−1x) dx.g\p{s} \coloneqq I_1\p{s} - \frac{1}{s - 1} = \int_0^1 x^{s-1}\p{\frac{1}{e^x - 1} - \frac{1}{x}} \,\diff{x}.g(s):=I1​(s)−s−11​=∫01​xs−1(ex−11​−x1​)dx.

Then by L'Hôpital's,

lim⁡x→0 (1ex−1−1x)=lim⁡x→0x−ex+1x(ex−1)=lim⁡x→01−exex−1+xex=lim⁡x→0−exex+ex+xex=−12,\lim_{x\to0}\,\p{\frac{1}{e^x - 1} - \frac{1}{x}} = \lim_{x\to0} \frac{x - e^x + 1}{x\p{e^x - 1}} = \lim_{x\to0} \frac{1 - e^x}{e^x - 1 + xe^x} = \lim_{x\to0} \frac{-e^x}{e^x + e^x + xe^x} = -\frac{1}{2},x→0lim​(ex−11​−x1​)=x→0lim​x(ex−1)x−ex+1​=x→0lim​ex−1+xex1−ex​=x→0lim​ex+ex+xex−ex​=−21​,

so the integrand is continuous on [0,1]\br{0, 1}[0,1], and so ggg is well-defined. Hence, the integral converges whenever s−1>1  ⟹  s>0s - 1 > 1 \implies s > 0s−1>1⟹s>0 and so ggg is analytic on Re⁡s>0\Re{s} > 0Res>0 by differentiating under the integral sign. We then have the representation

I1(s)=g(s)+1s−1,I_1\p{s} = g\p{s} + \frac{1}{s - 1},I1​(s)=g(s)+s−11​,

so I1(s)I_1\p{s}I1​(s) is analytic on Re⁡s>0\Re{s} > 0Res>0 except at s=1s = 1s=1, and it has a simple pole at s=1s = 1s=1, and so f(s)f\p{s}f(s) satisfies the same properties. To calculate the residue at s=1s = 1s=1,

lim⁡s→1 (s−1)f(s)=lim⁡s→1 ((s−1)g(s)+1+(s−1)I2(s))=1,\lim_{s\to1}\,\p{s - 1}f\p{s} = \lim_{s\to1}\, \p{\p{s - 1}g\p{s} + 1 + \p{s - 1}I_2\p{s}} = 1,s→1lim​(s−1)f(s)=s→1lim​((s−1)g(s)+1+(s−1)I2​(s))=1,

and this completes the proof.
